page_analysis.text_content:
Roofed porches on the 1st floor

How to determine if a porch is at least 50% open (using Fig 5 as an example)

Fig 5 Roofed 1st floor porch

Step 1: Determine the perimeter of the porch and divide it into
segments that will allow a comparison of closed and
open segments.

The perimeter of the porch in Fig 5 is shown below. It is the sum of
segments A throug G. It is 70 linear feet.

8

visual_elements.description: An isometric view of a two-story house with a roofed porch on the first floor. The porch extends along two sides of the house, with columns supporting the roof. The house has multiple windows. This figure is referenced as 'Fig 5 Roofed 1st floor porch'.

A top-down plan view of a porch, showing its perimeter divided into segments labeled A through F, with corresponding dimensions. The segments are: A (3'), B (8'), C (10'), D (7'), E (14'), F (24'). There is also a segment labeled G (4'). The diagram shows an L-shaped porch with an angled corner. Two doors are indicated on the angled corner.

technical_specifications.parameter: Total perimeter of porch (sum of A through G)

subheadings: How to determine if a porch is at least 50% open (using Fig 5 as an example)

additional_notes: Page number '8' is located at the bottom left corner.
The word 'throug' in 'segments A throug G' appears to be a typo and should likely be 'through'.
